parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post mentions Viktor Orbán, but not in the context of Romanian parliamentary elections.  It encourages Hungarian voters in Transylvania to participate in the election and ensure their own parliamentary representation. While it indirectly refers to candidates, it doesn't specifically name or endorse any particular Romanian parliamentary candidate.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its message is clearly intended to reach a wide audience of Hungarian speakers in Romania, not just a select few.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The primary objective seems to be encouraging voter turnout among the Hungarian minority in Romania, not specifically influencing votes for or against particular Romanian parliamentary candidates. The call to "ensure their own parliamentary representation" is general and doesn't promote a specific party or candidate within the Romanian electoral context.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post could be considered a form of political communication, but it doesn't strictly adhere to journalistic standards. It's a statement from a political leader, not an objective news report or analysis. However, it doesn't explicitly advocate for or against any specific Romanian candidate.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>While it expresses Viktor Orbán's opinion, it's presented as an encouragement to vote, not as a direct endorsement of specific Romanian candidates. The context is crucial here; it's about encouraging participation in the election, not manipulating votes for a particular Romanian party.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>479926927911020</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while related to an election, doesn't directly promote or discourage voting for any specific Romanian parliamentary candidate.  It focuses on encouraging voter participation within the Hungarian community in Romania.  The mention of Viktor Orbán, while a political figure, is not used to directly influence the Romanian parliamentary election. The call to action is general, urging voters to ensure their own representation, not to vote for a specific party or candidate in the Romanian context.  While the ad is politically themed and paid for, it doesn't meet all the criteria for electoral propaganda under Article 36 (7) of LEGE nr. 334 din 17 iulie 2006, specifically points (a) and (c).  The connection to Romanian parliamentary elections is indirect and doesn't constitute a direct attempt to influence the outcome.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>RMDSZ</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
